instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V_G3H_RTC? PP3V_G3H_RTC is a 3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state that powers the RTC circuit. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.23V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.79V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.20V
<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> = 0v 
<SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCQ_ANI_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_PMIC_VR_P2V5_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V

The board is very clean. No sign of anything liquid damage. Already replaced the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> due to it missing <SIGNAL>SSD0_PMIC_VR_P2V5_EN</SIGNAL> but that didn't change anything at all. There is also isn't any shorts on any of the rails that have 0v. 

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
threads.message:
Need to get SSD voltages, in order to complete DFU.
The power on sequence for this board was already posted on the forum.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oBr-qxYVfghYimgX6pwkNbwSjpQfYbKq/view?usp=sharing[/URL]
Check <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> corresponding signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
threads.message: I understood that but I guess I’m not sure where the ssd rails are created. This board does not have <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> on it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
threads.message:
No.
It seems like the boards with 2 nands, one on each side of then board, don’t have <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> and the boards that have 4 total, 2 on each side, do have <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>. I have multiple boards in which this is the case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
threads.message: Is the machine recognized in DFU at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
threads.message:
Is it.

In fact, I tried a revive and that fixed the issue. I didn't think that would be the issue since I thought you needed SSD power in order for a revive or restore to work. Good to know for future reference.

Thanks for the help and your time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power - Stuck at 19v .01A
threads.message:
Looks like in this case SSD voltages came back after T2 revive.
T2's SMC firmware part is stored on internal ROM.

Thanks for feedback.
